content.description: Stand start match on a jug on the left side of the face, then traverse right across slopers and crimps to a prominent jug about 10 feet off the deck. Look for an interesting thumbdercling hold just under the lip for the right hand about halfway through the traverse.
content.protection: Pad. It may be possible to top out after reaching the finish jug, but the branches from a nearby tree make it a somewhat sketchy proposition. Dropping off is recommended.
content.location: If you are facing the Diagonal Crack problem, walk around the boulder clockwise. Trapeze Artist faces roughly west. Look for a nearby boulder that can be stood upon to chalk up the holds.

climbs.name: Lazarus Boulder
climbs.fa: Matt King and Matt Komatsu in 1998

content.description: Sit start low on sloping ledges with great feet on the right. Move up the dihedral feature for a few moves, then do a long move across the gap to match on small crimps. do a huge dead point to a slopey lip.Location is west of the road about 60 yards and about 185 yards north of the pull-out parking for Steak Dinner Boulder. The easiest approach as of Summer 2021 is to walk up the road to where the cave is completely visible and a clearing allows access. Walk across the open area to where the canopy opens up on your left, south. Enter here and head south 20 yds. Other trails are overgrown.
Start with right hand in the obvious hueco and left hand on the the arete. Work straight up to an easy topout.
content.location: Walk up the road from the little pullover area about 185 yards, and cut in towards the mountain when you see a huge cave/arch. This will minimize bushwhacking. After about 45 yards in you'll walk past Holy Ghost which faces west toward the cave. This boulder is east of Diagonal Crack and Lazarus boulder in a brushier alcove.34.707493, -98.706289

content.description: I actually have no idea what the rating is on this. I haven't worked in very much, and even that was a couple years ago.This amazing crack is located about 60 yards to the left of the creekbed that runs through steak dinner parking, and about 180 yards NW of the parking spot as the crow flies, ~260 yds if you walk up the road and cut WSW into the brush when you see the cave, or 235 yds NNW of steak dinner if you take thick brushy trails (As of Summer 2021). 34.707399, -98.706603as far as i know, it's still a project (but my guess is that it's not actually that hard, if you can climb cracks).

Sit start in low slopey ledges with great feet on right (same as The Gash). Move up the dihedral and left into a crimp. Continue working up the dihedral until you can throw for the lip with your left hand. Work both hands to the very top of the dihedral, then press it out.Approach: Location is west of the road about 60 yards and about 185 yards north of the pull-out parking for Steak Dinner Boulder. The easiest approach as of Summer 2021 is to walk up the road to where the cave is completely visible and a clearing allows access. Walk across the open area to where the canopy opens up on your left, south. Enter here and head south 20 yds. Other trails are overgrown.

There are two really nice boulders just left of the stream (if approaching from steak dinner). The boulders can be reached by continuing about 200 yards upstream from Steak Dinner. There are also a few good problems on a bluff near the base of the mountain.  These have probably been climbed, but I don't know.  If you have any info about names, grades, or FAs, let me know.
